awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A New Approach to Particle Astrophysics with VERITAS and Multi-wavelength Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, and can be used to test fundamental physics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is a ground-based observatory designed to study high-energy gamma-rays. VERITAS has unique capabilities, providing high sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources. This award supports scientists at Iowa State University to carry out research with VERITAS. The group will work on new data analysis techniques to improve the study of spatially-extended sources and to facilitate the joint analysis of data from multiple observatories. Using these new analysis techniques the group will conduct a systematic study of Galactic sources of particle acceleration, and ultimately search for signatures of dark matter. The group will work with the Iowa State University planetarium developing multi-wavelength astronomy and high-energy astrophysics shows, displays, and demonstrations. 


The PI has adapted a maximum likelihood framework for VERITAS data analysis that will be extended to enable simultaneous fitting of data from multiple instruments. In addition, the PI will implement a new background estimation method based on this maximum likelihood framework that will improve the analysis of extended sources. Together, these developments will help maximize the impact of the VERITAS long-term science program. The PI will perform a systematic study of Galactic particle accelerators such as supernova remnants and pulsar wind nebulae, their interaction with their immediate environment, and the evolution of the particles they produce, along with more long-range work searching regions of high dark matter density for the gamma-ray signature of dark matter self-annihilation.

por.por_cntn:
Cosmic rays--primarily atomic nuclei and electrons--bombard the atmosphere of our planet from all directions. Because of the magnetic fields that thread through interstellar space, we cannot track these cosmic rays directly to their point of origin. However, the processes that accelerate cosmic rays to high energies are also expected to produce very high-energy photons (light particles) known as gamma rays. Gamma rays, which are unaffected by interstellar magnetic fields, can be tracked to their source and used to map and understand the phenomena responsible for accelerating cosmic rays to extremely high energies.

This award funded research in high-energy particle astrophysics at Iowa State University. The award focused on studying cosmic accelerators within our galaxy. These studies relied on data from the gamma-ray telescope VERITAS, combined with complementary data from other observatories such as the Fermi Large Area Gamma-ray Space Telescope. ISU scientists contributed to tasks critical to the operation of the VERITAS observatory, including observing shifts, data quality monitoring, analyzing and interpreting VERITAS and Fermi data, and preparing results for publication. The principal investigator also contributed scientific leadership from 2019-2022 as co-chair of the VERITAS working group focused on the study of Galactic phenomena. ISU scientists supported by this award contributed data analysis and interpretation to studies of cosmic ray acceleration in supernova remnants, pulsar wind nebulae, and VERITAS follow-up of extremely high-energy gamma-ray emission detected by the wide-field gamma-ray observatory HAWC.

The core work supported by this grant was the development of a novel method for analyzing data from VERITAS and other observatories like it. The method is based on maximum likelihood fitting and designed to improve VERITAS? ability to detect gamma-ray sources that covered a significant fraction of the VERITAS field of view. This work resulted in two PhD theses, each of which implemented and tested a distinct version of the method on VERITAS data. Studies done on simulated data using the first version of the method demonstrated substantially increased sensitivity to large-scale gamma-ray sources. The method performed fairly well on real data for sources with an extension of few tenths of a degree or less. Statistical and systematic uncertainties affecting the characterization of the cosmic ray background formed the primary limitation for larger regions of gamma-ray emission. The second version of the method was adjusted to reduce sensitivity to the systematic effects. It was also integrated into a new analysis framework (GammaPy) that is becoming more widely used in the gamma-astronomy community and provides infrastructure for fitting data from multiple instruments. Application of the method to VERITAS data on the Gamma Cygni supernova remnant produced encouraging preliminary results. The resulting map of gamma-ray emission revealed extended structure very similar to that seen in four times deeper observations by another gamma-ray observatory. This work also identified further changes needed to fully implement the method within GammaPy, including a modified maximum likelihood statistic and changes to the way GammaPy handles and interpolates background models.

The gamma-ray astronomy group at ISU shared the driving questions behind their research with the general public by developing new material for monthly shows at the ISU planetarium. These shows, run by ISU graduate students, reach a broad cross section of the community, from young children to adults. ISU scientists also developed and ran new Saturday workshop modules for the ISU Science Bound program. These Science Bound Saturday events introduced 9th through 12th grade students from under-represented groups to the excitement of scientific research and the range of possible STEM careers. Topics included the rich and significant afterlife of massive stars, the different views of the universe provided by different wavelengths of light, and the increasingly important role played by new astrophysical messengers such as neutrinos and gravitational waves. Each module included a planetarium show, interactive activities that allowed the students to explore in a supportive environment, and a Q&A session. In addition, the ISU group hosted a high-school student from an under-represented group every summer as a research intern.
